questiontext.text:
What value would x have to be assigned to give you a minimum value of {min}:

randNum = rand() % {max} + x;

What value would x have to be assigned to give you a range of {r} different numbers:

randNum = rand() % x + {min};

What is the max random number randNum could be?

randNum = rand() % {max} + {min};

In C++ why do we put the following line of code in our program when generating random numbers?

#include <ctime>

generalfeedback.text: Though not a requirement to use time() to set the srand() function, this is a very common practice as each time the program begins, the results of time() will be new as time does not stand still.

answer.text: The code to create random numbers is located in the ctime library.

feedback.text: Incorrect.  Using the time from ctime is a good way to seed srand().

answer.text: You need access to the system time to create random numbers.

feedback.text: Incorrect.  Using the time from ctime is a good way to seed srand().

answer.text: Using the time from ctime is a good way to seed srand().

feedback.text: Incorrect.  Using the time from ctime is a good way to seed srand().

questiontext.text:
What is the minimum value that randInt could be?

int randInt = rand() % 10 + 0;

What is the minimum value that randInt could be?

int randInt = rand() % 10 + 10;

What is the maximum value that randInt could be?

int randInt = rand() % 10 + 10;

What is the maximum value that randInt could be?

int randInt = rand() % 5 + 1;

How many possible different values could randInt be?

int randInt = rand() % 5 + 1;

How many possible different values could randInt be?

int randInt = rand() % 8 + 0;
In C++ the rand() function is used to generate a random number.

generalfeedback.text: Note: remember to call srand( time(NULL) ) to start the number generator with a different starting point each time the program is ran!

(Choose ALL that Apply)  Given the following declarations from the main function of a C++ program:

int alpha = 10;
float beta = 3.14;
char charlie = '\t';
bool delta = false;
std::string echo = "Row, row, your boat";

Which of the following lines of code are syntactically correct?

generalfeedback.text:
Correct:

std::string *s = &echo;

bool *b = δ

WRONG:

int *p = &echo;     --- 'echo' is declared as an integer

float *delta;        --- 'delta' has already been used above.

char *char =&charlie;   --- The name of a variable can not be a reserved word (IE char)

char *c = echo[0]        ---  'c' is a pointer, and holds a memory address to a character.  'echo[0]' is an character.

(Choose the Best Answer)

[[1]] - Only the value of a variable is passed to the function.

(Choose the Best Answer) What is the purpose of a function prototype?

answer.text: It informs the compiler and programmers alike what the function expects as arguments, as well as the kind of data it returns when the function is defined below main() or in a separate source code file.
A function prototype allows a programmer to to more easily experiment with a function before finalizing the code in the source file.
A function prototype is the term used when you reference a function inside pseudocode.
Experienced programmers do not need to prototype their code and therefore do not use function prototypes.

questiontext.text: (Choose ALL that Apply) Which of the following function prototypes are valid?

generalfeedback.text:
Correct:

int main2(int main1);
std::string stringAdder(std::string string1, std::string string2);

Incorrect:

int char(float myFloat); - A function's name cannot be a reserved word
int int-adder(int x, int y); - A function's name cannot have a "-" in it.
char mander(fire); - There must be a data type for the parameter.

answer.text: std::string stringAdder(std::string string1, std::string string2);
int int-adder(int x, int y);

questiontext.text: Match the following maintenance categories with their type of modifications.  Some categories may be used more than once or not at all.
(Choose the Best Answer) The Software Development Life Cycle has four phases, starting with the __________ phase.

feedback.text: Part of the Design Phase.

answer.text: Policies, system and network limitations and how they may affect the program

questiontext.text: (Choose the Best Answer) Once developers have deemed a program functional, this testing is completed by personnel who are not involved with coding the program.
(Choose the Best Answer) Which of the following is the LAST thing to happen in the Testing and Deployment Phase?
(Choose the Best Answer) Which of the following is a program that allows a programmer to step through a program one line at a time, and displays program state and variable values as it executes?

generalfeedback.text:
Debugger

A debugger, or debugging tool, is a program that allows a programmer to step through a program one line at a time.  Some popular debuggers are: Ollydbg, windbg, gdb, IDA Pro.

questiontext.text: (Choose the Best Answer) Which of the following prints the program state to a file and are very useful for recording the state of the system?

generalfeedback.text:
Logs

Similar to print statements, but instead of printing to a screen, the program prints the program state to a log file.  Logs are very useful to record state of the system and can serve as a vital aide in debugging as well as reporting bugs in the software.

questiontext.text: (Choose the Best Answer) Which of the following are added to display program state, variable values, or markers to help identify where an issue may reside in a program?

generalfeedback.text:
Print Statements

Print statements are added to display program state, variable values, or markers to identify where issues reside.  Examples include entering/exiting a function and returning values from functions.

questiontext.text: (Choose ALL that Apply) What are the different stages of the Design Phase of the SDLC?
(True or False) The Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) allows a programmer to use an unsystematic approach to software creation.

generalfeedback.text: The SDLC is a SYSTEMATIC approach.

questiontext.text: (True or False) Users should only be involved during the requirements phase to allow the developers time to work on solutions.

generalfeedback.text: Users should be involved at EVERY stage and major decision point to keep developers from having to rework the solution.

questiontext.text: (True or False) Debugging is a methodical process of finding and reducing the number of errors in a computer program to ensure it behaves as expected.
(True or False) The Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) allows a programmer to use a systematic approach to software creation.
(True or False) Users should be involved during all phases to ensure developers do not need to rework solutions.
(True or False) Debugging is the irregular process of finding and reducing the number of errors in a computer program to ensure it behaves as expected.

generalfeedback.text: Debugging is a METHODICAL process.

Select the correct keyword to free the dynamically allocated memory in the following code:

#include <iostream>
using namespace std;

int main()
{
    int *numbers = new int[4];
    for (int x = 0; x < 4; x++)
    {
        numbers[x] = x + 1;
    }
    for (int x = 0; x < 4; x++)
    {
        cout << numbers[x] << endl;
    }
    [[1]] numbers;
    return 0;
}
Which reserved keyword is used to unallocate dynamic memory?
Which keyword can a programmer use to allocate memory for an integer on the heap?

What is the issue with the following use of dynamic memory?

#include <iostream>
using namespace std;

int main()
{
    int *puppies = new int(10);
    cout << *puppies << endl;
    delete [] puppies;

    return 0;
}

answer.text: A memory leak occurs because the array version of delete is used with the single version of new.
A buffer overflow occurs because 10 integers are assigned into an array that is one element in size.
The compiler ignores the code because no one should try to "delete" puppies.

questiontext.text:
What is the issue with the following use of dynamic memory?

#include <iostream>
using namespace std;
int main()
{
    int *puppies = new int[4];
    cout << puppies[0] << endl;
    delete puppies;
    return 0;
}

answer.text: A memory leak occurs because the single version of delete is used with the array version of new.
The compiler ignores the code because no one should try to "delete" puppies.

generalfeedback.text: The new keyword is used to allocate memory for a single variable on the heap such as a float. Use new [] to allocate memory for an array.

Fill in the blank with the value that will display 5.

#include <iostream>

using namespace std;

int main()
{
    vector <int> vec1;
    vec1.push_back(2);
    vec1.push_back(3);
    vec1.push_back(5);
    vec1.push_back(7);
    vec1.push_back(11);
    cout << vec1.at( {1:NUMERICAL:=2#Correct!} );
    
    return 0;
}

generalfeedback.text:
Use the index position to print values in a vector.

The correct answer is: 2

questiontext.text:
Fill in the blank so that regardless of the size of the vector, all values contained in the vector will be printed:

#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <ctime>
#include <cstdlib>
using namespace std;

int main()
{
    vector <int> nums;
    srand( time( NULL ) );
    int y = rand() % 100 + 1;
    cout << "The vector is " << y << " elements long.\n";
    for (int x = 0; x < y; x++)
    {
        nums.push_back(x);
    }
    for (unsigned int x = 0; x < {1:SHORTANSWER:=nums.size()#Correct!}; x++)
    {
        cout << nums.at(x) << " ";
    }
    
    return 0;
}

generalfeedback.text:
Use the .size() method return the number of elements in the vector.

The correct answer is: nums.size()

Which function prototype represents the default constructor in the following code?

class House {
public:
     House() {
         //code
     }
     House( std::string outsideColor ) {
          //code
     }
     ~House() {
        //code
     }
     ~House( std::string newColor ) {
        //code
     }
     void changeOutsidePaint ( std::string newColor ) {
         this->exteriorColor = newColor;
     }
     std::string outsidPaintColor() {
         return this->exteriorColor;
     }

    std::string exteriorColor;
};

questiontext.text: Match the following from Day 8:
Match the following:
Match the following:
Match the following:
Name of the pointer that points to a succeeding node of the list.  If a NULL pointer, means you are at the end of the list.
Name of the pointer to a prior node of the list.  If a NULL pointer, means you are at first node of the list.
Name of the pointer to the first node of a linked list.  If a NULL pointer, indicates the list is empty.
Name of the pointer to the last node of the list.  If it points to the head node, then there is only one node in the list.
Each node of a linked list is located in memory between the previous node of the list, and the next node of the list.

feedback.text: An array is continuous memory locations.  A linked list is non-continuous memory.

questiontext.text: Linked lists, in contrast to an array, cannot grow in size after its creation.

feedback.text: This just the opposite, arrays cannot grow in size, a linked list can grow in size.

questiontext.text: Linked lists are a good data structure to use if many changes are needing to happen as all you need to do is change where pointers are pointing.
A singly-linked list's nodes only contain a "next pointer" and always starts at the "head node" to transverse the list to a node.

feedback.text: This fact makes searching or transversal of a linked list slow, even if it all the data is stored in an orderly manner (IE alphabetically for string data)

questiontext.text: A doubly-linked list's nodes only contain a "next pointer" and always starts at the "head node" to transverse the list to a node.

feedback.text: This is a singly-linked list's description.  This fact makes searching or transversal of a linked list slow, even if it all the data is stored in an orderly manner (IE alphabetically for string data)

questiontext.text: A doubly-linked list's node has pointers to the next and previous nodes and is allowed to go in either direction when traversing the list.

feedback.text: Though faster at times, it still has to step through each node to find the desired node, even if it all the data is stored in an orderly manner (IE alphabetically for string data)

feedback.text: A debugging tool (debugger) allows you to step through a program and shows the current values in memory.

(True or False) A debugging tool is not referred to as a debugger.

generalfeedback.text: The gdb is a debugging tool.

questiontext.text:
What is the output of this code snippet?

int a = 6;
int b = 3;
int *c = &a;
int *d = &b;

a = *c  + a;
b = *d + b;
*c = b + a;
*d = *c + b;

cout << b << endl;

What value would x have to be assigned to give you a minimum value of 18:

randNum = rand() % 5 + x;

What value would x have to be assigned to give you a range of 8 different numbers:

randNum = rand() % x + 7;

What is the max random number randNum could be?

randNum = rand() % 5 + 2;

What is the final value of counter that is printed if counter is set to 6?


int counter = 6;
while ( counter % 4 != 0 ) {
    cout << "Counter is " << counter << endl;
    counter--;
}

What is the final output of this code?

int counter = 0;
for ( counter = 5; counter < 45 ; counter += 7 ) {
     cout << counter << endl;
}

What is the final printed value?

int counter = 8;
while ( counter < 21 ) {
     counter += 3;
}
cout << counter << endl;

What is the last number printed?

int counter = 0;
for ( counter = 4; counter > -3; counter -= 2 ) {
     cout << counter << endl;
}
cout << counter << endl;

What is the final printed value? 

int counter = 4;
while ( counter > -5 ) {
     counter -= 2;
}
cout << counter << endl;

What is the last value printed?

int counter = 0;
for ( counter = 6; counter <= 15; counter += 2 ) {
   cout << counter << endl;
}
cout << counter << endl;

What is the final printed value?

int counter = 3;
while ( counter <= 14 ) {
     counter += 3;
}
cout << counter << endl;

What is the last line of output of this code?

int counter = 0;
for ( counter = 17; counter >= 14; counter -= 1 ) {
     cout << counter << endl;
}
cout << counter << endl;

What is the final printed value?

int counter = 87;
while ( counter >= 76 ) {
     counter -= 2;

questiontext.text:
What is the output of this program?  (A stack diagram may help.)

#include <iostream>
using namespace std;
int calc_value(int *variable);
int main(void)
{
   int a = 16;
   int *pa = &a;
   a *= calc_value(pa);    // What is being sent to the function?
   cout << “The value of ‘a’ is: “ << a << endl;
}
int calc_value(int *variable)
{
   *variable /= 2;
   return *variable;
}

OUTPUT
The value of 'a' is: ___

feedback.text: pa is a pointer, and holds a's address (points to a).  Thus when we pass pa into the function, variable (also a pointer) now holds a's address (points to a).

questiontext.text:
Analyze the following code and determine the output.

void mystery(int *x)
{
   int num = 0;  
   *x *= *x;
   return num;
}
int main (void)
{
   int num = 4;  
   mystery(&num);
   std::cout << “The answer is: “ << num << std::endl;
}


OUTPUT
The answer is: _____

feedback.text: "*x *= *x;" is same as "*x = *x * *x;" and since x is a pointer to num, that becomes 4 * 4 which is then stored into num.

questiontext.text:
Complete the below description of the Stages of Compilation:

Combines multiple [[1]] files in the [[2]] stage into a(n) [[3]].

The [[3]] then goes to the [[4]] stage and is converted into [[5]].

[[5]] is sent to the [[6]] stage and is converted to [[7]].

Lastly, the [[7]] goes to the [[8]] stage and is saved as a(n) [[9]].

generalfeedback.text:
"SLAM PCAL 'cuz it's LAME" 

SLAM is the first letter of the inputs
PCAL is the first letter of the stages
LAME is the first letter of the outputs

-or-

S - P - L
L - C - A
A- A - M
M - L - E

bool myBool = true;
if (myBool) {
    std::cout << "a";
}
else if (myBool == true) {

(Fill in the Blank) What is the output after the following code is executed?

std::string myString = "The quick brown dog jumped over the lazy programmer.";
int myInt = 5;
if ( myInt < 0 ) {
    std::cout << myString[0];
} else if ( myInt < 5 ) {
    std::cout << myString[1];
} else if ( myInt < 10 ) {
    std::cout << myString[2];
} else {
    std::cout << myString[3]; 
}

feedback.text: myInt < 0 is false, so this line,  std::cout << myString[0];, would not execute.
myInt < 5 is false, so this line,  std::cout << myString[1];, would not execute.  And remember, myString[1] is an "index" and indexing starts at zero, so "T" would be myString[0].
myInt < 10 is true, so this line,  std::cout << myString[2];, would execute.
C++ is case sensitive.  Also, look at the question again....(hint: "T" is not the answer).

name.text: 2 Code blocks print the same (logically equivalents)

questiontext.text:
(True or False) The following two code blocks are logically equivalent:

Code Block 1
if (myBool1 == true || myBool2 == true)
{
     std::cout << "We are inside the if statement";
}

Code Block 2
if (myBool1 == true)
{
     std::cout << "We are inside the if statement";
}
else if (myBool2 == true)
{
     std::cout << "We are inside the if statement";
}

feedback.text:
The || is the "logical or" operator so the first code block reads as "IF myBool1 OR myBool2 ARE true, DISPLAY 'We are inside the if statement'".

The second is in an if-else if-else structure which reads as "IF myBool1, DISPLAY 'We are inside the if statement' ELSE IF myBool2, DISPLAY 'We are inside the if statement'".

Or as they would stay in Mod 2 ------(b1 ^ b2) -> p;  (b1 -> p) , (b2 -> p)
where b1 is myBool1, b2 is myBool2 and p is the print statement.

questiontext.text:
(True or False) Evaluate the following Boolean expression and determine if it's true or false.

Declaration
int x = 10;

Expression
( x = 0 )

generalfeedback.text: A common mistake for new programmers is to use a single equal sign (=) instead of the double equal sign that is used for a comparison (==) in conditions for loops and if statements. The single equal sign indicates an assignment. As you can see here, this can create a hard to find bug when your logic isn't executing as you expect. (x = 0) will always evaluate to false, but (x == 0)  will be true if x has previously been set to 0.

questiontext.text:
(True or False) Evaluate the following Boolean expression and determine if it's true or false.

Declaration
int x = 0;

Expression
( x = 10 )

generalfeedback.text: A common mistake for new programmers is to use a single equal sign (=) instead of the double equal sign that is used for a comparison (==) in conditions for loops and if statements. The single equal sign indicates an assignment. As you can see here, this can create a hard to find bug when your logic isn't executing as you expect. (x = 10) will always evaluate to true, but (x == 10)  will only be true if x has previously been set to 10.

What is the final value of counter printed, if counter is set to {c}?

int counter = {c};
while ( counter % 4 != 0 ) {
     cout << "Counter is " << counter << endl;
     counter--;

name.text: if loop is FALSE, do execute.

questiontext.text:
Complete the following statement:

If the condition of a loop is [[1]], then the loop's body will [[4]].

(Fill in the Blank) What is the final output of this code snippet?

int counter = 0;
while ( counter < 10 ) {
    if ( counter % 2 ) {
        counter += 2;
    }
    else if ( counter % 3 == 0 ) {
        counter = 3;
    }
    else if ( counter > 6 ) {
        counter -= 1;
    }
    else {
        counter += 1;
    }
}
cout << counter << endl;

generalfeedback.text:
Remember, if the condition is only an integer, then zero (0) is false, and every thing else is true.  
With that knowledge, (counter % 2) evaluates to false first time through the loop, so we go to ( counter % 3 == 0 ) which is true and sets counter to 3.
Now for the rest of the iterations (counter %2) is true and we just add 2 to counter.  
The (counter > 6) and the final else never get checked or executed in this code snippet.

feedback.text:
Counter's value at the end of each iteration:
3
5
7
9
11
When counter is 0, the first condition of the if is false ( 0 == false ), so we go to the next condition which is then true.

questiontext.text:
(Fill in the Blank) What is the final value of counter printed?

int counter = 4;
 while ( counter != 0 ) {
      counter--;
     cout << "Counter is " << counter << endl;
}

feedback.text: Counter's value is decremented before it prints, so the loop would go back to the condition one more time.

questiontext.text:

     counter ++;
}

feedback.text: If counter was 8 when checking the loop's condition, then the condition would be false and the loop body would not execute.

questiontext.text:
(Fill in the Blank) What is the final value of counter printed?

int counter = 4;
while ( counter != 0 ) {
     cout << "Counter is " << counter << endl;
     counter--;
}

feedback.text: This is the final value of counter, but is is never printed to the screen.

questiontext.text:
(Fill in the Blank) What is the last value of counter printed from this code?

int counter = 0;
for ( counter = 7; counter <= 10; counter += 1 ) {
    cout << counter << endl;
}

feedback.text: Great Job!
One off error!  When counter is 11, the condition will be false, and the body will not execute.
Check the condition again.....

name.text: last value printed FOR loop with %

questiontext.text:
(Fill in the Blank) What is the last value of counter printed from this code?

for ( counter = 10; counter % 6 != 0; counter  -= 1 ) {
    cout << counter << endl;
}

feedback.text: Great Job!
Only an assignment can change counter.  "counter % 6" will not change counter's stored value.
Check the condition out again.....
Check out the loops change statement.....

questiontext.text: (True or False) If a continue statement is encountered inside a for or for each loop, a change executes before starting the next loop iteration.

feedback.text: Nice.  You halt all execution of the loop and set the loop up for the next iteration by conducting the Change.
continue halts the current iteration, and begins a new iteration, so yes you MUST execute a change.

questiontext.text: (True or False) If a continue statement is encountered inside a while loop, the change statement executes before the condition is checked again.

feedback.text: Incorrect.  HALT all execution of the loop and GO immediately to check the condition.
Correct.  Halt all execution of the loop and go immediately to check the condition again.

(Fill in the Blank) Given the following code, what is the output:

#include <iostream>
using namespace std;
int main ( void )
{
    int a = 10;
    int b = 20;
    int *c = &a;
    for ( int d = 0; d < a; d += 2 ) {
        *c -= b % 3;
    }
    cout << a << endl;
    return 0;
}

generalfeedback.text:
Since *c points to a, a's value will decrease by 2 each loop iteration while d's value increase by 2 each loop iteration.

Comparison of  d < a for each iteration of the loop:
d < a
0 < 10
2 < 8
4 < 6
6 < 4

questiontext.text:
(Fill in the Blank) What is the output of the following code?

int stuff( int one, int *two, int *three )
{
    int C = 0;
    C = one + *two + *three;
    *two *= *three;
    *three += *two;
    C += one + *two + *three;
    return C;
}

int main()
{
    int a = 2, b = 4, c = 5, d = 0;
    int *cPtr = &c;
    d = stuff( a, &b, cPtr );
    cout << "a = " << a << ", b = " << b << ", c = " << c << ", d = " << d;
    return 0;
}

feedback.text: Right values but insure that there are no spaces or comma at the end of the line.
Right values but insure that there are no spaces or comma at the end of the line.

questiontext.text:
(Fill in the Blank) What is the output of the following code?

int stuff( int one, int *two, int *three )
{
    int C = 0;
    C = one + *two + *three;
    *two += 1;
    *two *= *three;
    *three += *two;
    C += one + *two + *three;
    return C;
}

int main()
{
    int a = 2, b = 4, c = 5, d = 0;
    int *cPtr = &c;
    d = stuff( a, &b, cPtr );
    cout << "a = " << a << ", b = " << b << ", c = " << c << ", d = " << d;
    return 0;
}

(Fill in the Blank) What is the output of the following code?

int factorial( int n )
{
    int answer = n;
    for( int fact = n - 1; fact > 1; fact-- )
    {
        answer *= fact;
    }
    return answer;
}

int main()
{
    int num = 4;
    int f = factorial( num );
    cout << num << "! = " << f;
    return 0;
}

questiontext.text:
What is the output of the following code?

int adder(int *vals, int size)
{
    int total = 0;
    for(int index = 0; index < size; index++)
    {
        total += vals[index];
    }
    return total;
}

int main()
{
    int values[10] = {5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, 50};
    int answer = adder( values, sizeof(values) / sizeof(int) );
    cout << "The total is: " << answer;
    return 0;
}

What is the output of the following code?

int adder( int first, int val )
{
    int answer = 0;
    answer = first + val;
    return answer;
}

int main()
{
    int values[10] = {5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, 50}, total = 0;
    for( unsigned int index = 0;index < sizeof(values) / sizeof(int); index++ )
    {
        total = adder( total, values[index] );
    }
    cout << "The total is: " << total;
    return 0;
}

Which of the following containers can change in size?
Rank the following containers in order from smallest memory usage to largest, assuming each is holding 100 integers currently.

generalfeedback.text:
100 integers == 100 x 4 bytes == 400 bytes just to store the integers.

1 pointer == 4 btyes for our purposes here.

Arrays - 400 bytes - as they exactly the size for each element
Vector - 404 bytes - the heap array and a pointer.
Linked List - 804 bytes - 100 integers, 100 pointers per node, plus the "Head Node" pointer.

questiontext.text: Which of these containers that can change in size has to reorganize where elements are in memory (move memory locations) each time you insert or delete from the middle of the container.

generalfeedback.text: An array is fixed in size;  A vector is an dynamic array, and requires its elements to "move" either left or right in memory to add or delete an item in the middle.  A linked list requires only a change of a single pointer, but the Nodes do not have to physically move.

questiontext.text: Determine which container(s) are fast to transverse using pointer arithmetic due to how they are laid out in memory, and which one(s) are slow due to having to go from the first element/node to the next until you find the element/node you desire.

answer.text: Goes from one to the next

questiontext.text: Which of the following containers requires the most memory and processing time to increase from its starting size?

generalfeedback.text: Remember an array cannot change in size and adding a Node to a Linked List will always take the same amout of processing and memory.  A vector when it doubles in size, will take up memory for two different arrays and then has to do a copy operation in memory, moving the data from the old array into the new array.

feedback.text: Can not change in size
Requires two dynamic arrays when it "doubles" in size, with the old array's data being copied (a processor intensive job) to the new array
Will use the same prococessing and memory every size increace

questiontext.text:
Choose the best container to use given the following scenario:

You are writing a program and you need to store information about each student and their grades in your class.  You have created a Student class to represent each of your classmates and to hold their individual module grades.  Now you need to store each student.  You will need to add new students only, (former students will just be marked in the Student class as to which module they left the class). Order in the container is not important.  Each student's data should be quickly accessed using a pointer.

feedback.text: Has to be able to change in size, a static array is a fixed size only.
Correct!

Students must be "quickly accessed using a pointer";  Linked lists require you to go from the first node to the next to the next until you find the desired information.  Thus are sssssssssslllllllllllllllllllllloooooooooooooowwwwwww, and not fast.

questiontext.text:
Choose the best container to use given the following scenario:

You want to keep track of all daily high temperatures in Pensacola for the month of March.  You want this container to be the most efficient in look ups and memory use.  (Note the numbers of days will not change regardless of the year.)

feedback.text: The amount of days will not change.
A good secondary option, but requires a little more memorry and a little slower than just an array. (Since it does not change in size, double is not an issue.)
Never a choice for "quickness".  And requires at least twice the memory of just a static array to it Next Node Pointers

questiontext.text:
Choose the best container to use given the following scenario:

You have been tasked to write a widget tracking program.  You have already created a Widget class that will hold all the data for a single widget, but your boss needs you finish the program by storing all the widget objects in one container.  The number of widgets will be changing constantly as they wear out and new ones are created.  The number of widgets will not be known, as some may be put into storage before an older one has to be replaced.  As per the program requirements, look up time is not an issue, but having to rewrite large sections of memory will take too much processing and needs to be avoided.

feedback.text: Fixed in size so not an option.
Inserting or deleteing from the middle becomes processing and memory intensivie operations as the array elements are shifted.  Lets not even think about the "doubling" in size....
Never a choice for "quickness", however adding a new Node requires the same processing power and memory no matter where in the list you place it.

questiontext.text: How many pointes will a single node of a singely linked list contained?
A mechanism to store data elements in sequential memory locations.
A mechanism to store data elements in a logically ordered manner with each element having a pointer to the next element in the container.
What is a single element of a linked list called?
The first node of the linked list is known as the ___ node
A pointer belonging to a node, that holds the address of the following element of the linked list.
A ___ list has a pointer to both the previous and next nodes, allowing traversal of the list to be done both forwards and backwards.

feedback.text: Don't forget the hyphen.  (It is a "Doubly-Linked" list.)

questiontext.text:
Finish this C++ program that askes the user for their age and then their name and then prints a message to the user with their name and age.  Remember you need to prompt the user prior to input.  The output should look as shown below and in the sample results.

Desired Output:

Hello <name>, that is a great name.
You are <age>.

generalfeedback.text: Remember that input can be tricky. Using cin is great because it will convert the input to the datatype we try to store it in, but it my not work so great with strings.  Strings can have spaces which is what cin will read up to, so to capture the whole input you need to use getline() and if a cin was used previous to the getline() the ws() function is also required.

question.template:
import os import re
sa = """{{ STUDENT_ANSWER }}""" lines = sa.split("\n") code = "" numberofprompts = 2 for line in lines: if (re.search( "\s*cout", line ) and numberofprompts > 0): numberofprompts -= 1 continue code += line + "\n" fout = open ("test.cpp", "w") fout.write(code) fout.close() exitcode = os.system("g++ -std=c++11 -o test.exe test.cpp") if ( exitcode == 0 ): os.system("./test.exe") else: print("===== Compiler error!!!! =====")
os.system("rm test* -f")

Hello Alley, that is a great name. You are 24.
Hello Frank, that is a great name. You are 18.
Hello Bjarne Stroustrup, that is a great name. You are 70.

questiontext.text:
This program will print out the results of two inputted numbers using the four basic math operator and modulo.  You will need to create five variables that will each hold the resulting calculations, and also perform the math operations and store them the correct variable which are then printed out in the provided cout lines.  You will need to read the code to find the variable names.

(Note: In this program assume that you will not divide by zero for any operation.)

Using the provided template, complete the program so that it will get 2 inputs (integers) from the user, and then display the inputs back to the user utilizing the 5 math operators (+, -, /, *, %).
Lines to complete are: 21, 23, 25, 27 and 29

generalfeedback.text:
With programming there are mulitple ways to solve each problem. In the solution provided the math is part of the cout statement in the output. You could however save each of the results into new variables and then display those variables in the output section.

You might have also noted that in one of the test cases 5 / 25 = 0 and that can seem incorrect. The important point here is that a and b are both integers which impacts how operators work with them. When we do math with integers, we will get integers back. This is why modulus or % are useful, because this allows are to see the remainder or leftovers after we complete the integer division.

expected.text: Enter a number: Enter another number: 18 + 5 = 23 18 - 5 = 13 18 / 5 = 3 18 * 5 = 90 18 % 5 = 3
Enter a number: Enter another number: 5 + 25 = 30 5 - 25 = -20 5 / 25 = 0 5 * 25 = 125 5 % 25 = 5

questiontext.text:
The following program will print off the following information about an inputted string using the string methods as found in the Student Guide.
  • The inputted string
  • The length of the string
  • The first letter of the inputted string
  • The last letter of the inputted string
  • The inputted string with the first letter changed to 'L'
  • The location of the sub-string "um" in the inputted string

Use the declared variables to hold the results of processing and enter your code below the indicated comment.

Remember to read the code first to better understand what variables you need to use.

generalfeedback.text:
To use methods we use the object name with dot notation. In this question because the string variable is userInput, we can use all the string methods with the following syntax userInput.<method name>()

When getting or setting letters in a string you will always use the index location. With the index you can either use square brackets, or the .at(<index>) method.

Remember that the length gives us the number of characters starting its count at 1. Therefore the last index(index starts at 0) will always be one less than the length.

stdin.text: I love MOD 3, is it so much fum!

expected.text: Enter a string: UserInput: I love MOD 3, is it so much fum! UserInput lenght: 32 UserInput first letter: I UserInput last letter: ! UserInput with changes: L love MOD 3, is it so much fum! Location of "um" in userInput: 29

stdin.text: The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy hound dog.?!0123456789

expected.text: Enter a string: UserInput: The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy hound dog.?!0123456789 UserInput lenght: 63 UserInput first letter: T UserInput last letter: 9 UserInput with changes: Lhe quick brown fox jumped over the lazy hound dog.?!0123456789 Location of "um" in userInput: 21

questiontext.text:
1. Create a new file and save it as ex3-9_finPlannerPT1.cpp. This program calculates the amount of retirement money earned if investment starts today and progresses at a fixed rate. The program should complete the following:
    1. Initialize a constant integer equal to the current year.
    2. Prompt for the following information.
      • Birth Year
      • Annual Income
      • Contribution Rate
      • Retirement Age
    3. Calculate the number of years until retirement, the retirement year, and the total account balance at retirement age.
    4. Display information back to the screen.
      • Retirement Year
      • Number of Years to Retirement
      • Annual Income
      • Contribution Rate
      • Total Contributions at Retirement

question.template:
#This code will remove the first X lines that start with "cout" { "^\s*cout" } #and remove them from the code prior to compiling and running the code.
numberofprompts = 4 import os import re # Gets the students' input and splits into a list by lines sa = ''' {{ STUDENT_ANSWER }} ''' lines = sa.split("\n")
#removes the fist X lines with "cout"s code = "" usedConstCorrectlly = False linenumber = 0 for line in lines: linenumber += 1 if ( re.match( r"const\b", line.strip() ) ): tokens = line.strip().replace("const","",1).strip().split('=') if ( len( tokens ) != 2): usedConstCorrectlly = False break else: try: integer = tokens[1].split(';')[0] if not ( ( ( tokens[0].split()[0].startswith( "int" ) ) ) and ( int( integer != 0 ) ) ): usedConstCorrectlly = False break else: usedConstCorrectlly = True except : pass if (re.search( "\s*cout", line ) and numberofprompts > 0): numberofprompts -= 1 continue code += line + "\n" if ( usedConstCorrectlly == False ): print( "You must use a constant integer for the current year.") exit(127); #save the files and run the file fout = open ("test.cpp", "w") fout.write(code) fout.close() exitcode = os.system("g++ -std=c++11 -o test.exe test.cpp")
#if the program does not compile print a warning message to help students. if ( exitcode == 0 ): os.system("./test.exe") else: RED=r"\033[0;31m" print( ''' ========================== =>> Compiler Error <<= ========================== ''' )
os.system("rm test* -f")

expected.text: Retirement year: 2062 Number of years to retirement: 41 Annual Income: $50000 Contribution Rate: 6% Total Contribution: $123000
